Situation1: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story: I was looking forward to a quiet day at home, lounging in my loose, comfortable clothes with my family. As a Muslim, I always make sure to dress modestly, especially when I’m not expecting to leave the house. But just as I settled in, my phone buzzed—a message from the pool manager. The morning swim lessons were about to start, but a lane rope had snapped, and no one else was available to fix it. As the lifeguard on call, I was expected to maintain the equipment and make sure everything was safe and ready. I glanced down at my relaxed, modest clothes, knowing I’d have to change into my work uniform—shorts and a fitted shirt—if I went. The thought made me uneasy, torn between my responsibility to the pool and my commitment to my faith. My mind raced, weighing the urgency of the broken rope against my desire to honor my beliefs. I stood in the hallway, heart pounding, caught between two worlds and unsure which expectation I should meet.
